etymology.description: semantic: 虫 “snake/insect” + phonetic: 延 (OC *lan, *lans); later abbreviated 延 → 疋; non-contracted form 蜑; refers to snake eggs.
etymology.interpretation: 虫 signals the semantic field of creatures like snakes or insects, evoking the idea of eggs. 延 provides the sound, later written in the shortened form 疋, while the fuller form 蜑 made the snake association explicit.

examples.chinese: 我早餐吃两个鸡蛋(我早餐吃兩個雞蛋)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zǎocān chī liǎng gè jīdàn.
examples.english: I eat two eggs for breakfast.

examples.chinese: 他这个王八蛋又骗人了(他這個王八蛋又騙人了)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zhège wángbadàn yòu piànrén le.

examples.chinese: 他不小心被球砸到蛋(他不小心被球砸到蛋)，疼得直不起腰(疼得直不起腰)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bù xiǎoxīn bèi qiú zá dào dàn, téng de zhí bù qǐ yāo.
examples.english: He was accidentally hit in the testicles by the ball and couldn’t straighten up from the pain.
